raw_text:
Ireland win eclipses refereeing 'errors'
 
 The International Rugby Board may have to step in to stop frustrated coaches and players from publicly haranguing referees when things go belly-up.
 
 It may have to go the whole way and have NFL-style video cameras all over the field, or slap the vociferous perpetrators over the knuckles. What the IRB does not want is a football scenario where the verbal slanging matches often overshadow the game itself. Sunday's explosive Six Nations clash at Lansdowne Road was a good example as Ireland took another step towards their first Grand Slam since 1948. The game was as exciting as it comes, with a much-improved England side enraged at a few decisions that did not go their way. One can understand that frustration. There was no doubt that Ireland had the rub of the green in their 19-13 victory, but the reaction from the England camp may not have endeared them to the sport's "blazers". Referee Jonathan Kaplan was not perfect by any means and two decisions in particular made him the villain of the piece. I doubt whether Kaplan would have been too pleased at the comments made. After all, he has no public recourse to criticism.
 
 It was the same for Simon McDowell, the touch judge who was heavily criticised by Scotland coach Matt Williams after their defeat against France. As far as England were concerned, there were queries over Mark Cueto's first half-effort when he went over in the corner from a Charlie Hodgson kick.
 
 England coach Andy Robinson referred to a similar case at Ravenhill in January when Ulster were playing Gloucester in the Heineken Cup. On that occasion, David Humphreys kicked to Tommy Bowe, who touched down in the corner only for the try to be wiped out. But you cannot have cameras at every conceivable angle to pick up such anomalies. Perhaps Robinson was right to say the referee should have gone upstairs when Josh Lewsey was driven over the Irish line near the end.
 
 Lewsey claims he touched it down and was in full control. However, one has to credit Ireland flanker Johnny O'Connor for cleverly scooping the ball away and blocking any evidence of a touchdown. But in rugby, everything tends to even out over the 80 minutes. The referee also missed England's Danny Grewcock taking out Ronan O'Gara off the ball to allow Martin Corry a Sunday stroll to the line. Those were the stand-out moments in a classic game between the two old foes.
 
 But there were many more, and one should not take away from those. Brian O'Driscoll's winning try was as well-conceived as they come, while Charlie Hodgson's brilliant kicking display was another highlight. And Ronan O'Gara's tremendous ability to control the game was also a crucial component. But the defining moments came with Ireland under the cosh in the final 15 minutes. Two outstanding pieces of defensive play denied England and allowed Ireland to hold on. The first was Denis Hickie's brilliant double tackle in the right-hand corner. He gobbled up Cueto from another Hodgson cross-field kick, then regained his feet to stop Lewsey from scoring a certain try. Ireland's second-row colossus Paul O'Connell was equally superb. England had turned Ireland one way then the other, and the defence cordon was slowly disintegrating. England prop Matt Stevens ran in at full steam to suck in a few more tacklers. Unfortunately he ran into O'Connell who hit him hard - very hard - and then wrestled the ball away for a crucial turnover. That spoke volumes about Ireland's back-foot display, with defensive coach Mike Ford taking a bow at the end. To win a game like that showed that Ireland have moved forward. It may be tries that win games, but it is defence that wins championships.
llama3.2:1b:
Ireland and England clashed in the Six Nations rugby match, with Ireland emerging victorious 19-13. The game was marked by intense frustration from both teams' coaches and players. 

Referee Jonathan Kaplan made several errors, including two decisions that many felt were not correct. Simon McDowell's touch judge role was heavily criticized after his mistakes were revealed.

Coach Andy Robinson also expressed frustration with certain calls, although he acknowledged the need for cameras to review key moments like Josh Lewsey being driven over the Irish line near the end of the game.

Ireland's defense, led by Johnny O'Connor and Paul O'Connell, made several crucial plays that denied England opportunities.
llama3.2:3b: Ireland won a thrilling Six Nations match against England with a 19-13 victory. Referee Jonathan Kaplan was criticized for several decisions, including allowing an English try that was likely ruled out due to the ball being held by an Irish player. The match featured many contentious calls and close moments, but ultimately Ireland's defense, led by Paul O'Connell's double tackle, proved decisive in securing the win.
gemma2:2b: The International Rugby Board (IRB) needs to address the issue of coaches and players criticizing referees' calls.  England was particularly frustrated after losing their match against Ireland with concerns about refereeing decisions. While video cameras might help, the IRB may need to implement stricter measures. The 2010 Six Nations match between England and Ireland provided a glimpse into this issue; despite Ireland winning, they benefited from favorable calls that fueled post-game criticism of the referees.  The article highlights various missed calls by the referees that influenced the outcome of the game. Ultimately, while Irish defense proved to be key in securing victory, the game itself remains a complex topic with potential for debate and controversy.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ireland won six-against-six in the Six Nations rugby tournament after controversial referee Jonathan Kaplan made several unsportsmanlike decisions. The game was full of controversy and criticism from both sides, with England coach Andy Robinson referring to a similar incident at Ravenhill in January when Ulster were playing Gloucestershire. The referee missed the crucial moment by not going upstairs when Josh Lewsey was driven over the Irish line near the end of the match. England's top players, including their try-scorer Danny Grewcock and their defensive coach Mike Ford, are credited with a defining moment in the game.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland secured their first Grand Slam since 1948 after defeating England in the Six Nations final with Jonathan Kaplan's controversial refereeing. The match highlighted poor decision-making and aggressive play by both teams, including England's overzealous tackling and Ireland's robust defense, culminating in a dramatic win that showcased improved discipline and defensive capabilities.
qwen2.5:3b: Ireland defeated England in a highly competitive Six Nations clash, highlighted by several key moments including outstanding defensive plays and impressive performances from players such as Brian O'Driscoll, Charlie Hodgson, and Ronan O'Gara. Despite referee Jonathan Kaplan's perceived errors, particularly regarding decisions that did not go England's way, the game showcased Ireland's improved performance compared to previous years, culminating in their first Grand Slam since 1948. The match demonstrated the importance of defensive strategies over individual try-scoring opportunities in securing rugby victories.
opencoder:1.5b: Ireland has been criticized for being a tough country to play in due to its aggressive, defensive tactics. The game between England and Ireland was one of the most memorable occasions IRL played since 19th century when they won the World Cup, although it wasn't until 20th Century and 21st Century that Ireland have seen the rise of rugby.

The International Rugby Board may have to step in to address this issue and find a solution that allows for more transparency in decision-making. However, it is important to strike a balance between allowing the game to be played and ensuring that players' actions do not overshadow the sport itself.

Despite the numerous highlights in this match, it was evident that Ireland's back-foot display was instrumental in securing their win. The Irish team demonstrated a significant improvement compared to previous games, showing they have moved forward.

The game was marked by contentious refereeing decisions favoring Ireland, with England coach Andy Robinson and players expressing frustration. Notable controversies included Mark Cueto's try and potential touchdown, as well as Danny Grewcock's hit on Ronan O'Gara that led to a crucial try for England. Despite these issues, the match was characterized by exceptional rugby plays from both teams. Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll scored the winning try, while Charlie Hodgson showcased his kicking skills and Ronan O'Gara demonstrated excellent game management. Key defensive moments for Ireland were Denis Hickie's double tackle on Cueto and Paul O'Connell's forceful play to halt Matt Stevens, highlighting Ireland's strong back-foot performance. The win underscored the importance of solid defense in rugby, suggesting that while tries are vital, championship success often hinges on stout defensive work.
